South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

div.head: Motor Buses for Alexandria.
div.p: The twenty two new motor buses for th Hyptian Motor Traction Company will arriv in Alexandria in four months' time.

div.head: Cab Tariff.
div.p: The Cairo Gouvernorat is revising the taril for public cabs. Native papers are almos animous in demanding the introduction o saximeters.

div.head: The Brindisi Mail.
div.p: The mail from Europe via Brindisi and Por Said (P. and 0.) will be distributed at th Alexandria Port Office at half past four thi afternoon.

div.head: Sudan Ordinances
div.p: 'The Sudan Government has issued two or dinances regulating the entry of vessels into the harbour of Port Sudan and the licensing of lighters for work in that harbour.

div.head: Scorpion Bite.
div.p: Another death has occurred from a scorpion sting. A little native boy Mohamed Mousse by name, died yesterday in the Abbassia quar ter from the effects of a sting received on Monday last. Births and Deaths. *** 512 births, of which 7 are of European parentage, and 748 deaths, of which 19 are Europeans, were registered in Cairo during the week ending 22nd instant. 602 of the death were of children under 5 years of age.

div.head: To Stop the Crisis.
div.p: According to the Mokattam" the Com mittee of the Cairo Bourse has received tw anonymous letters embodying a threat tha the premises of the Bourse will be blown up with dynamite should the full in prices con tinue.

div.head: A New School,
div.p: Yesterlay the foundation stone of a schoo to be erected at Sembellawine by Osman Bey Salit, was laid down by the Mudir of the province, amid a considerable gathering o rintables of that locality. Osinan Bey Sali has endowed the School with ten feddans o the best agricultural la nd.

div.head: Fatal Marriage Feast.
div.p: Ahmed Ganem and his bride and guests were attacked with severe pains immediately after partaking of the marriage feast. Poisoning was diagnosed by the doctor who was called in, and has been proved to be due to verdigrifrom unclean copper pans. One of the guests has succumbed.

div.head: Provincial Water.
div.p: The Superior Municipal Commission has taken in hand the question of providing the principal provincial centres with filtered water and has sent engineers to the provinces to report on whether it would be more advisable to sink artesian wells for the purpose, or to convey and filter water from the Nile.

div.head: Windsor Hotel
div.p: A special programme of music is to be given at the Windsor Hotel this evening by the Rivier 3rchestra, the items of which are a follows:-March. Fleur de Hongrie, Popy Fantasie, Samson and Delilah, St. Saens Serenade, for the violincello, Braga ; Lucia de Lammermoor, Donizetti; Ave Maria, Gounod Tannhauser, Wagner; Invocation, Ganne Enchantement, Roussean.

div.head: The Bourse Lane.
div.p: A correspondent writes to complain of the lisgraceful state of the lane behind the Alex andria Bourse leading from Cherif Pasha Street to Tewfik Pasha Street. The native fruit ilers there are most disorderly and fight and quarrels are of frequent occurence there Tite windows of Mr. Callebotta's newspaper shop were smashed at 2 p.m. on Monday during a fight between Europeans and natives over some fruit. The Alexandria Municipality and the police seem to be quite powerless to restrain the incessant.rowdiness prevailing there."

div.head: Brutal Attack.
div.p: On the pretext that they had been give short measure, when making a purchase o some fruit, in the Ataba el Khadra two Italiane named Eurico and Giuseppe Della Chiesa brutally attacked the vendor, Ibrahim Gada! lah, and severely wounded him with repeated blows of a dagger. As the disturbance tool place just outside the Mixed Tribunal, severa policemen were about, and the agressors wer inmediately arrested and have been beer handed over to their consulate. The victim o the oatrage has been taken to hospital and i in a very precarious condition.

div.head: Covernment Schools.
div.p: The latest issue of the "Journal Officiel publishes the following decrees issued by th Ministry of Education : 1. A decree abolishing the examination for admission to the Secondar Schools. Holders of the Primary Education Certificate will be admitted without examir ation. 2. A decree fixing a new distribution of recitation hours at the Secondary and Prim ary Schools. 3. A decree giving a new syllabu for drawing which was approved by th Council of Ministers on the 2nd July last. 4. 2 decree giving the new syllabus for Secondary Schools which was approved by the Council o Ministers at its meeting of the 2nd instant.

div.head: THE KHEDIVIAL VISIT TO GENEVA.
div.p: -- (Gaxotto's Spocial Service.)

London Wednesday. The Khedive, accompanied by two English! officers and a large suite has arrived at Geneval and visited the school where he was educated, before leaving for Divonne-les-Bains. He will visit England before returning to Egypt.

div.head: THE LAMBERT AFFAIR. RESIGNATION UNDESIRED.
div.p: Sir E. Grey informed Mr. Robertson that M. Lainbert's resignation was not desired. There was no intention whatever of not keeping the agreement of 1904 in spirit and in letter, in Egypt and elsewhere.

div.head: CUSTOMS ADMINISTRATION. ADDRESS TO CHITTY BEY.
div.p: As a tribute to the success of Chitty Bey's management of the Customs Administration while he held the post of Director General at Alexandria, the native merchants of this city, intend to present him with an address in Arabic, bound in an handsome cover of true oriental design. The cover is framed in gold and old silver designed as the doorway of a mosque with the capitals of the columns in lace pattern, and in the centre is an inscription in gold.

div.head: MR. MONTAGU SUMMERS ON EGYPT'S STABILITY.
div.p: Interviewed by a representative of a London newspaper, Mr. Montagu Summers, managing director of the Egyptian Estates, Limited, said he would make some very important pronouncements at the company's general meeting to be held on Friday. In his opinion, the prosperous position of Egypt was in no way affected by the present financial crisis, which was due chiefly to over-speculation on the Bourse by a certain section of the European population. He viewed the outlook for Cairo property in a most optimistic light. Nothing conld stop that city from greatly extending. The cotton prospects for next season were most hopeful, and the fact that something like 120,000 tourists had visited Egypt last winter season, and had spent, in his estimation, not less than 18 millions sterling, while it was absolutely certain that this portion of the country's revenue would go on increasing year by year, were factors to be considered in a review of the situation. British and foreign capital for the development of the country would be forthcoming in an increased degree, and under the wise direction of Sir Eldon Gorst, British investors' could have nothing but the fullest confidence in the great future of the conntry.

div.head: THE PLAGUE
div.p: During the week ending the 22nd inst., fourteen cases of bubonic plagne were registered thronghont Egypt, of which 7 occurred at Alexandria, 1 at Port Said, 1 in the district of Beba and 5 in that of Damanhour. From the 1st January to 22nd instant, 999 cases of plagne were recorded in Egypt, as against 385 cases registered during the corresponding period of last year.

For the past 24 hours the following particalars are given :-3 recoveries, I admission to and 2 deaths in hospital at Alexandria and 1 death in hospital at Damanhour. 16 patients remain under treatment.

div.head: QUARANTINE MEASURES
div.p: The Director of Quarantine at Suez telegraphed to the Ministery of the Interior, under date 21st July, stating that a suspected case of plague had been discovered on board a British steamer "Clan MacNeil," arrived at Sucz from Bombay and bound for Hull. The crew, consisting of 68 men, has been carefully examined and subjected to disinfection and quarantine, until medical reports have been given upon the suspected case.

div.head: THE FINANCIAL CRISIS. EFFECT ON IMPORT TRADE.
div.p: We recently published the result of our enquiries on the subject of the cotton crop, as/ affected by the present financial crisis, and we sball to-day consider the position of the im port trade in the same light. Our enquiries into the latter branch of commerce have been attended with greater difficulties owing to its numerous branches, and to the different conditions under which it is pursued. A raw article like cotton is always more pasily negotiable (that is more readily converted by sale into cash) than an article of manufacture and whereas advances are always procurable on warrant for cotton, silk, wool, piece goods, etc., the manufactures of such products are not considered bankable security to the same extent. Bearing in mind this fact, we realise that relatively more credit is required for the conduct of the import than for the export! trade of this country; and the safety of the trade depends on the caution with which such credit is extended.

The branch of the import business most serionsly affected by the crisis is the Man chester and soft goods trade, which until recent years, was mainly in the hands of old established houses possessed of considerable capital and with long experience of the requirements of the trade of the country and the responsibility of their customers. The merchant in such cases gives from four to five months credit and receives from the buyer a promissory note which is regarded rather as an acknowledgement of debt, which can be easily enforced, than as a negotiable bill, and, when the note has run for some time, weekly pay, ments are made on account, but the full amount of indebtedness is never discharged at maturity.

Of recent years several Levantine firins, former customers of the old import houses, have entered into competition with them, and having established branches in Manchester and elsewhere, have sought to extend their transactions in Egypt. To this end they have been compelled to offer advantages which the older honses refused to grant, among which extended credit has been the alluring bait. As a consequence the accounts, which were formerly turned over 2 times per annum, have worked more and more slowly, and now cannot be turned over more than 1| times in the same period.

The natural resnlts have followed : more capital has been required to conduct the trade: annual profits have fallen in proportion to the diminished rate of turn-over; working expenses have increased enormously, the dearness of living entailing increased wages, salaries etc. while the increased length of credit has, as is! invariably the case, resulted in a larger per centage of bad debts. Overtrading has resulted in a great accumulation of stock and conse quent lock up of capital, the liquidation of which must necessarily be a work of time.

The situation has, however, been aggravated by the circulation of a large amount of bills drawn by some of the large importers on their branches in Manchester and elsewhere, which have been negotiated to a considerable extent by the banks in this conntry. That the ultimate loss in respect of them will, according to the telegrams from London which we have published, be comparatively small, is a matter of congratulation, although due to luck rather than to judgment on the part of the holders. We have been unable to ascertain what "value received" these bills represented ; clearly they were not drawn against shipments ; they may, of course, have represented debts due to the drawers or they may have been covered by remittances of other bills of exchange purchased here.

At certain periods of the year Egyptian Banks require to remit gold to London, and, if they can purchase bills payable at short date, it is often more convenient to do so than to ship gold. Provided a bill can be sold at one or three days' sight, it is an exceedingly simple operation to cover it by remittance of first class commercial paper at three months' date, which can be discounted to provide for the short-dated paper, and, indeed, the ability to draw bills payable on demand or within a week enhances the reputation of the drawers. Paper which is actually or virtually payable on demand has often lured a banker, to al pitfall, especially when, away from the control of his Board of Directors, he has in time acquired too great confidence in his own I judgment and a contempt for the opinion of others.

Importers have for some time complained that their interests have been sacrificed by the banks, who have diverted the funds at their disposal in favour of speculators in stocks and shares, and we find on referring to our file, the following forecast of the situation at the end of May from an ocasional contributor to our columns whose position lends weight to his criticisms. "It therefore appears to me that the financial world/ will make the commercial world suffer for their mistakes by stopping the regular flow of credit !"

The position of the trade to-day more than confirms our correspondents' judgment, for not only are the bonded warehouses crowded to rapletion, but the goods now arriving from Manchester are not even removed from the landing sheds of the shipping companies.

The prospect is not cheerful, but we are of opinion that the banks here will in their own interest have to give assistance to the trade. Fortunately the directors of many of the larger banks have for several years placed considerably more of their profits to reserve than they have divided in dividends, and the reserve fund in many cases exceeds the paid up capital ; nor have they as far as we can see allowed their gold reserve to run below the level of safety. We therefore consider them fully able to resume the normal credit to importers and we assume that common sense will direct their policy when they have recovered their nerves.

Regarding the petition to the Government which is being hawked about for signature, asking for State interference with the object of assisting the import trade, we consider it so foolish an exhibition of utter childisbnes that we hope no responsible firms will, with! thoughtless good nature, lend their names td! support the promoters. We believe the Govern! ment have given, and may be confidently relied upon to give, all reasonable assistance at this period, but surely it exceeds the bounds of prudence to ask them to relieve certain bankers of the consequences of their acts during a period of frenzied speculation:

That the latter may not be enjoying a tranquil period at present is more than probable, not on aceount of sparcity of funds, but on account of the unanimity of public opinion against the reckless manner in which they have conducted their business. They will probably emerge from the hot water, into while they have plunged, subdued and wiser men and will in the future confine their attentions to the humble round and trivial task of commercial banking, and not attempt again to scale the giddy heights of speculative finance.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA MUNICIPALITY. THE ANNUAL REPORT.
div.p: Chataway Bey bas issued his report on the accounts and progress of the Alexandria Municipality during the past year, and on the whole the document affords satisfactory reading. The receipts show a continual upward movement and a still further increase will take place next year when the ootenniel revision of the home rents will be made. The prosperity of the city is evidenced by the working of the financial departments of the Mnnicipality. Chataway Bey draws special attention to the heavy expenditure which will have to be made on drains and roads, over and above the many other improvements which are needed in the near future. The fands for these big works must be forthcoming from the sales of the town lands, but a large suin must be in hand before the lands can be sold and the various annuities encashed. These works necessitate a considerable amount for upkeep, and this can only be found by raising the taxes. There is no doubt that the taxes Alexandrians now pay are very small in comparison with similar cities in Europe and if the town is to be kept up as it should be, in the style in which a European city of the same sort is run, the taxes must be increased. The Municipality is always being pestered with petitions for extending the system of public lighting, for repairing streets, making new roads, etc. But the applicants for these luxuries do not consider where the wherewithal for these works are to come from, and if the city is to be improved, it can only be by bringing the taxes ap to a European standard.
The proceeds from the sales of the quay lands goes to some extraordinary expenditure. The expenses for the upkeep of these works must come from the ordinary receipts.
Considerable progress has been made during the past year by the reorganisation of the technical services of the Municipality,

Chataway Bey draws special attention in his report to the extraordinary dilatoriness in legal procedure here, which renders it almost impossible for the Municipality to pursue persons guilty of contraventions. He gives the following instance :--

Par exemple: un individu gocupe illégale. ment la voie publique ; il est mis en contravention; finalement, il est condamné à une amende de quelques piastres, et tenu à rendre la voie libre. Ce devoir incombe à la police ; elle exécute l'ordre, et une ou deux semaines plus tard l'individu récidive, et les mêmes difficultés se représentent. Il est vrai que la police pent faire procéder à un nouveau déguerpissement des lieux sans avoir à recourir à un autre jugement, mais on conçoit aisé. ment qu'elle ait autre chose faire que de constamment enlever du payé un étalage illégal. Ce qu'il faut, c'est une punition sgvère, une forte amende aves emprisonnement pour désobéissance ou plutôt défi an jugement du Tribunal. J'attite à ce sujet votre attention sur les observations contenues dans la note du Seorétaire Général.

The Park and Plantation Service is doing good work. Nouzha Gardens are becoming more and more popular Next year it is to be hoped that & satisfactory solution in regard to the extension of the tram line thither will be arrived at.

The Sckvanging Department is working regularly but the problem of how to dispose of the filth and rubbish of Alexandria still awaits solution, and will not be settled until the new bridge over the Mahmoudieh Canal has been built and a furnace for getting rid of the rubbish constructed on the opposite bank.
The Slaughterhouses, Museum and Library all show good progress.

div.head: THE VIVANTE MYSTERY. THE ADOPTED THEORIES.
div.p: There are but two topics of general public interest in Alexandria at the present moment--the financial crisis, and the Vivante mystery, nationalism having ceased to interest and become merely a stop-gap. The "man in the street" is deeply interested in the Vivante affair and anxiously awaits a solution to the crime. There are also those who merely possessing the knowledge that there is a "Vivante affair", are anxious to obtain details. As an instance of this we have been told (though we are inclined to discredit it) that an over zealous newspaper reporter repaired to the hotel where the crime was committed and with unconscious but grim humour demanded from the boab "Khawaga Vivante foq ?"

In considering the various theories offered in explanation of the murder, the first of these to be dealt with is, that the assassin's real intention was to rob the jeweller oocupying the adjacent, and communicating, room. This, however, is scarcely admissable. A travelling jeweller would naturally keep the door of his room locked and bolted; a wardrobe in front of the door made entry impossible from Vivante's room; and it can safely be presumed that the man who committed so cleverly planned a murder, and ran such great risks of detection in the act of the crime had most carefully studied all details.

The second is that the motive was to rob Vivante. This, however, we cannot accept, for it is incredible that Vivante wonld carry upon him so great a sum of money as to provoke the most daring criminal to commit a murder against such chances of discovery. Vivante, moreover, was known to be a careful and prndent man, and never to carry upon him large sums of money.

It has also been suggested that the object of the assassin was to avenge a real or imaginary wrong. In such a case, again, the risk incurred was too great. That the crime was committed in cold blood cannot be doubted, and many far easier, safer, and surer methods of hastening his enemy to his grave would have come to the avenger's mind. That such a mode of murder would be adopted for the sake of petty vengeance is quite incredible.

The only possible theory, indeed, is that the murderer was convinced that the death of Vivante was absolutely necessary to him, and at the earliest moment possible. Vivante and he must have had mutual interests, or the former must have been in possession of fatally incriminating information concerning the latter, the divulgence of which would have led at least to ruin, for the crime was exceptionally desperate and daring. The murderer possibly lived in terror of the man whom he so dastardly garrotted.

As far as we can discover, the attention of the police has up to the present been mainly directed towards tracing the mysterious fair young man, with a visiting card of Mr. de Bellegarde, so frequently alluded to, and who, the proprietor of the hotel avers, could be uphesitatingly identified by his staff out of a large crowd. This is hard to believe, the man having only engaged the room on the evening of the murder and left it early the following morning. It might be that the failure to discover the assassin is due to too much concentration on one suspected individual, or, again, perhaps, to slowness in formulating theories and obtaining clues.
Yesterday the luggage, clothes, papers, and letters etc. of Vivante were minutely examined at the Greek Consulate, but no clue was afforded by them.

div.head: COTTON WORM.
div.p: The following is the report of the Ministry of the Interior on the cotton worm during the week ended the 17th instant;
The provinces of Assiout, Beni Sonef, Minieh and Keneh remained immune.
In Behera, 34,384 feddans in 253 villages were infected and 27,686 feddans cleared.
In Dakahlieh, 3,945 feddans in 106 villages were infected ard 3,685 cleared.
In Fayoum, 4 feddans in one village were infected and cleared.
In Gharbieh 3,211 in 76 villages infected and 3,153 cleared.
In Ghizeb, 488 feddans in 5 villages were | infected and cleared.
In Menoufieh, 614 feddans in 3t villages were infected and 594 cleared
In Kalioubieh, 2,223 feddans in 114 vill. ages were infected and cleared.
In Sharkieh, 873 feddans in 16 villages were infected and cleared.

div.head: MOTOR BUSES FOR SUEZ
div.p: The Egyptian Government has granted a concession to an Alexandrian resident for a passenger and freight service for Suez for twenty years.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: The Moss liner "Seti" arrived this morning from Liverpool via Gibraltar, Algiers, and Malta, with passengers, mails and general cargo.
The S.S. Carib-Prince, with passengers and general cargo, left Malta on the 23rd inst, and is due to arrive at Alexandria on Saturday,

There has been a fairly considerable influx of visitors from Cairo and Alexandria, who have come to spend a few weeks in the invigorating climate in or around Troodos. In whichever part of the Island one may travel at this time of year evidences are afforded that the first and chief business of the large majority of the people is agriculture. At present all hands are busily engaged on the threshing floors, and the large stacks of wheat, barley and oats, of flax and aniseed, betoken a good agricultural year. On either side of the as railway line between Trimithia and Morphon the land is given up to market gardens, which just now are yielding their annual crop of watermelons. The whole ground throughout that locality seems smothered with this creeping plant whose large, luscious, though somewhat flavourless fruit, is deservedly popular in this parched country. The high-filled, top-heavy looking mule waggons, laden with these fruits, have been for many years a familiar sight, as they lumbered along the Morphon-Nicosia or Nicosia-Larnaca Road. The weight of these unwieldy cart loads is great, and the roads are generally at their worst at this time of year. One is therefore led to indulge the humane hope that the advent of the railway to these parte, offering as it does a more rapid means of conveyance, will be availed of by merchants in place of the old fashioned method, and thus afford relief to many a wretched over-driven beast of burden.

The inhabitants of Nicosia have lately become aware that they possess a town band. It appears to have been formed for some time, but as it never performed in public, it was for all practical purposes non-existent. The Municipality has now taken the very proper and popular step of allowing its musical achievements to be placed at the disposal of the public on one evening in the week, and the performances it has so far given in the Government gardens (commonly described as 'the Park') have been very creditable and enjoyable.

A Law which was passed in the last session of the Legislative Council, requiring all public vehicles and carts to be numbered, and of regulating the fares payable in respect of public conveyances, will shortly come into force.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: It is confirmed that the Khedivah Mother has abandoned her intention of performing the pilgrimage to the Hedjaz for the present. It is stated that her Highness took this decision on the instance of the Khedive, who expressed the desire to have the journey postponed in view of the progress that is being made with the Hedjaz Railway which his Majesty stated, will be completed in a few years, when the Khedivah Mother will be able to perform the journey by rail.
Sir Horace Pinching, Director General of the Public Health Department, left yesterday morning for Damietta on a visit of inspection. He will return to Cairo in three days.

The new Catholic Armenian Bishop of Alexandria, Monsignor Pierre Kayounian, was enthroned at Constantinople on Friday last at the Patriarchal Church at Rue Sakis Agatch Pera. The ceremony was conducted by the Latin Armenian Patriarch Peter XII. The new bishop will shortly leave Constantinople for Alexandria.

The Sultan has conferred the 3rd class of the Medjedieh on Mohomed Bey El Naggari, judge at the Cairo Mixed Tribunal, in recognition of the service he has rendersed to science by his compiling a French-Arabic encyclopedia dictionary.
Three months leave of absence has to been granted to Captain G. Harding, A S.C., dating from the 3rd prox.
Second Lieutenant Thomas G. Rice has resigned his commission in the King Rifle Corps.
Sister M. MacGregor, Q. A. I. M. N.S., has been granted leave of absence for 35 days from date of disembarkation in England on S.S. "Irrawady," due to leave Alexandria on Friday next.

div.head:
THE SUEZ CANAL
RETURN OF SHIPPING AND TONNAGE.
div.p: A parliamentary paper has just been issued giving the returns of navigation through the Suez Canal for the past year, as compared with those of the two previous years, 1904 and 1905.
The net tonnage for the past year shows an increase of 311,399 tons as compared with that of 1905, and an increase of 43,669 tons as compared with that of 1904.

From the 1st January, 1906, the rate of transit dues was reduced from 8 fr. 50 c. to 7 fr. 75 c. per ton. This reduction had its effect upon the gross receipts, which amounted in 1906 only to 108,161,896 fi. as against 113,866,796 fr. in 1905.
The number of vessels which passed through the Canal was 4,237 in 1904, 4,116 in 1905, and 3,975 in 1906, of which 2,679 in 1904, 2,484 in 1905, and 2,333 in 1906 carried the British flag...

There has been a decrease of 57,009 tons last year as compared with 1905 in the tonnage of British vessels, which aimounted to 8,833,929 tons in 1904, 8,356,940 tons in 1905, and 8,299,931 tons in 1906. During the same period, the tonnage of German vessels has increased from 1,969,561 tons in 1904 to 2,113,484 tons in 1905, and to 2,155,552 tons in 1906.

The percentage of British vessels and their net tonnage decreased in 1906, being 58.7 and 61.7 respectively, as against 60.4 and 63.6 in 1905 and 63.2 and 65.9 in 1904. The percentage of German vessels and their net tonnage. was 14.8 and 16.0 respectively, as compared with 14.6 and 16.1 in 1905, and 12.8 and 14.7 in 1904, while the percentage of net tonnage of the other maritime nations using the Canal in 1906 remained practically stationary as compared with the preceding year.

Of 2,948 merchant-vessels and vessels in ballast, of a net tonnage of 9,819,008 tons, passing through the Canal, 2,103 ships, of a net tonnage of 7,338,032 tons, were British, being fully 71.3 per cent. of the number and 74.7 per cent. of the tonnage; 328, or 11.1 per cent, were German vessels, whose tonnage was. 11-2 per cent. of the whole; France, Holland, Russia, Austria-Hungary, Denmark, Norway, and Turkey combined furnishing a total of 16.4 per cent. of the vessels and 13.3 per cent of the tonnage of the carrying trade to the East through the Suez Canal.

In the ten years 1891-1900, the annual net tonnage ranged from 8,698,777 tons to 9,738,152 tons, and the transit receipts from 83,422,101 fr. to 90,623,608 fr. The average of the net tonnage was 8,588,947 tons; and of the transit receipts 80,006,013 fr.; while in 1906 the net tonnage amounted to 13,445,504 tons, and the transit receipts to 108,161,896 fr. The mean net tonnage per vessel, which in 1881 was only 1.517 tons, rose from 2,067 tons in 1891 to 2,926 tons in 1901, and to 3,383 tons in 1906.
The Canal was used 32 times by steamers. exceeding 150 mètres (492 feet) in length or more than 18 mètres (59 feet) in breadth, with a draught of over 7 mètres 80 (25 feet 7 inches).

The percentage of vessels drawing less than 24 ft. 7 in. (7 m. 50c.) was 79.7 in 1906 as against 82.8 in 1905, while that of vessels drawing more than 24 ft 7 in. was 20.3 in. 1906 as compared with 17.2 in 1905.

Up to the end of the year 1901, the maximum draught allowed for vessels passing through the Canal was fixed at 25 feet 7 inches, and during 1906, 804 vessels, drawing more than 24 feet 7 inches, used the Canal, as compared with 708 in 1905 and 705 in 1904, representing a percentage of 16.7 in 1904, 17.2 in 1905, and 20.2 in 1906. Since the 1st January, 1908, the maximum draught of water allowed has been raised from 26 feet 3 inches (8 mètres) to 27 feet (8 mètres 23), and 135 vessels, or 3.3 per cent., took advantage of this alteration during the past year.
It is believed that a notice will shortly be issued that the draught allowed will again be raised from the 1st January, 1908, to 8 mètres 53 or 28 feet.

It may be interesting to observe that the draught allowed at the opening of the Canal was 7 mètres 50 or 24 feet 7 inches, which was raised to 7 mètres 80 or 25 feet 7 inches on the 15th April, 1890, to 8 mètres or 26 feet 3 inches on the 1st January, 1902, and to 8' mètres 23 or 27 feet on the 1st January, 1906. The mean duration of passage for all vessels navigating the Canal was 18 hours 35 minutes in 1905 as compared with 18 hours 2 minutes in 1906, while the percentage of vessels navigating by night amounted to 96'1 per cent. in. 1905 as compared with 96-7 per cent. in 1906.

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY.
div.p: The 2nd Battalion Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers will embark on the S.S. Soudan at Alexandria about the 14th February next en route for home. The battalion, on arrival, will be stationed at Dublin. The Fusiliers would no doubt prefer a station much nearer to where the bulk of the rank and file hail from, and it would have been as easy to arrange for the battalion to be stationed at Londonderry and Enniskillen as at the Irish capital. Both stations are within the territorial district of the regiment, and both will be vacated this season by the 4th Battalion Middlesex Regiment, which will be replaced by an English battalionthe 1st Battalion Hampshire Regiment.

Lieutenants's S.F. Newcombe, and R.E.M. Russell, Royar Engineers, both attached to the Egyptian Army as assistant surveyors in the Railway Department, have been promoted to the rank of captain. Both received their com missions in June, 1898, and both are decorated for the South African War, Captain Newcombe having been employed with the Mounted Infantry in the operations Orange Free State, including the actions of Paardeberg, and the relief of Kimberley (Queen's medal with four clasps), and Captain Russell was through the operations in the Transvaal, Cape Colony and Orange River Colony, 1901-02 (mentioned in despatches, Queen's medal with three clasps).

Colonel Harry Finn, C.B., who recently retired from the appointment of Inspector General of the Commonwealth Forces (with the local rank of major general) has just gone on his well earned retired pay. Colonel Finn began the career of arms as a private soldier in the 9th Queen's Royal Lancers, in which his brother was a squadron serjeant major, and rose to the same rank himself speedily. He earned much credit in the Afghan War, gaining the Distinguished Conduct Medal-the equivalent of the D.S.O. and mention in despatches (medal with clasp ), and subsequently getting his commission in the 21st Hussars. now Lancers. With the 21st, he rode in the wild charge at Omdurman, and there earned a brevet lieutenancy colonel (Khedive's and British medals with clasps) and he got his C.B. last King's birthday list.

The "new" bullet which is to revolutionise modern war by all accounts is not so new after all. It more than a year since it was experimented with by civilians, who obtained very satisfactory results. The valuable data ob tained at Bisley this year will give the War. Office experts plenty of material to go upon. It is an open question whether the bullet or the new explosive by which it is propelled, or both, is the factor in the matter.

Vice Admiral Prince Louis of Battenberg having transferred his flag from the battleship "Prince of Wales" to the battleship "Venerable" in his capacity of second in command of the Mediterranean Fleet, Captain W.B. Fawckner, from the former battleship has been appointed flag captain of the "Venerable" familiarly known as the "Archdeacon" for obvious reasons.
The divisions of the Mediterranean Fleet are to have a passage trial to a point off Rhodes on the 23rd inst.

It is understood that the Admiralty has decided to make provision in the next ship building programme, for the leaving down of a new type of amoured cruiser, for police duties in the more remote waters of the Empire. It may be recalled that within recent years, the Admiralty went in for the policy of selling out of the service a large number of small cruisers whose fighting and defensive. powers were a negligible quantity, following on the decision to draw them from various waters where they had done police and other duties. The recent regrettable affair at Jama ica-where the humblest cruiser flying the white ensign would have been a veritable God send-and the troubles at St. Lucia and elsewere, it is stated, have convinced the Admiralty that a new type of ship of some fighting power is necessary for daty in the Pacific, East Indian, Australia, and China waters, and other remote parts where the showing of the flag periodically is an abso lute necessity if we are to maintain our place as the premier naval power. The new class of ship will be a cross between a second class cruisier and the ships of the Duke of Edinburgh type. The water line will be protected by a belt, the armament will consist of 7.5 inch guns-the recent Vickers-Maxim gan-and a speed of 28 knots will fit the cruisers for every duty, and the coal bunker capacity for obvious reasons will be very large.

div.head: AN EGYPTIAN JOURNALIST.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."

Dear Sir,-To those who are acquainted with the habits and failings of the Editor of "El Minbar" the latest effusion from his pent will afford much entertainment! The horror of Hafiz Effendi Awad at the immorality of Paris is really an amazing piece of humbug. It seems that following his usual bent he frequented the most notorious of the Parisian cafés where he knew the denizens of the half world were to he encountered. Having thus sought them out in their own province so to speak, he proceeds to express a pions horror at what he saw there!

div.head: GOVERNMENT EMPLOYEES.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."

Sir, This is a much debated question and is really worthy of some very strong criticism. One hears all sorts of complaints from the employees themselves and not less from the long suffering public. To take the latter side first, one hears an enormous amount of grumbling of the slow coach methods of the Government Offices; one is prone to reproach. the staff first and lose sight of the fact that the Government system is very very slowly emerging from its chrysalis state of native red tape (infinitely worse than European red tape) and a very, low degree of extreme corruption.

Admitting, however, this drawback, the servants of the country often lack politeness to the public, and their dilatory methods, apart from the red tapeisnt which is their unhappy heritage, are exasperating to the business man whose time is exceedingly valuable.

To criticise their personal habits is going a bit far, but it is infuriating to see a fat creature calmly drinking his coffee and puffing a cigarette when one is waiting for information or papers which may mean the losing or winning of a considerable amount to the commercial man. More particularly is this. annoying in the realising of monies due; an individual may have some thousands of pounds to draw and owing to the gentleman responsible for the passing of his account being so busy watching the clock for the hour when he grabs for his tarbouche and goes home, the cash. office is shut before the poor civilian can get the necessary formalities completed, thus losing for twenty four hours, funds extremely necessary for the carrying on of his business and the meeting of his liabilities.

A more serious point to the writer's mind is the indiscriminate granting of leave to the principals, without any ordinary business re gard of the necessities of the work and the convenience of the public: to put it plainly the various Government offices are practically paralysed during the summer months simply for the want of a little care in the arrangements of leaves of absence, and this more particularly in the higher grades. The inefficiency of some of these latter is simply astonish ing and in a service where handsome salaries are paid it is indeed astonishing that the best men for the positions are not forthcoming. Reflections, not based on jealousy, are rampant regarding the appointments of the higher officials of British, nationality, and the corresponding appointments of other Europeans who are very often of equal, if not greater capacity, and to a right thinking man having the general interests at heart it seems fully evident that a fairer adjustment might be arrived at.

Admitting that Great Britain has put ber hand to the plough here, and naturally wishes her sons to benefit by her investment, yet why not maintain a standard of excellence and sustain the credit of the nation by sending its best instead of a large number of imcompetents; it is quite natural that other nationalities in Government employment resent having other than really capable men placed over them.
The object of the influx of incompetent men is difficult to understand but it has been truly remarked that Egypt has become a dumping ground for younger sons and Varsity failures'.

There are a few of the best in the Government, but for Heaven's sake let those who can really judge a man have a chance in making a selection when any post is to be filled, so that a Civil service may be built up on similar lines to India and other places where they don't accept wasters. Truly yours,

div.head:
MUNICIPALITE D'ALEXANDRIE.
DELEGATION MUNICIPALE
div.p: La Délégation Municipale s'est réunie hier après-midi, sous la présidence de Schiess Pacha. Elle a pris conmissance d'une note pré- sentée par l'inspecteur sanitaire relativement aux propositions faites par lui au Conseil quarantenaire, au sujet des conditions de transport et du séjour dans les pares quarantenaires do bétail arrivant de Smyrne.

Elle-a exprimé le veu de favoriser autant que possible l'amélioration de la qualité de la viande consommée en ville, en facilitant l'importation du bétail d'autres pays et a décidé | d'inviter les services à faire, observer rigoureusement le règlement interdisant l'introduction et l'abatage d'animaux malades dont la viande n'est pas apte à la consommation.
Elle a décidé la construction d'étables où seront nourris et entretenus les animaux en attendant leur abatage.

La Délégation s'est ensuite occupée du choix d'un nouvel emplacement pour y déposer les immondices de la ville, l'emplacement actuel au quartier Toubguieh étant trop rapproché de la ville. Elle a choisi un emplace ment au-delà du Canal Mahmoudieh et a décidé de construire un pont en bois, du côté de la rue Ragheb Pacha pour le transport des immondices de l'autre côté du Canal. Ce pout coûters 550 livres et le crédit nécessaire sera demandé à la Commission Municipale.
Communication a été donnée d'une lettre Ministérielle approuvant le projet de la jetée promenade au Port-Est, de M. Joseph, sauf quelques légères modifications approuvées par la Délégation.

Sur la demande da 3me Cercle d'Irriga tion, la Municipalité prendra à sa charge aussi la construction du troisième pont sur le Canal Mahmoudieh, outre les deux autres qu'elle doit construire, d'apr's l'accord avec le Gouvernement.

Vu l'état sanitaire de la ville, la Délégation a décidé de promulguer d'urgence un arrêté interdisant le commerce des chiffons. -M. l'Administrateur a présenté, en dernier lieu, au membres de la Délégation, son rapport sur l'exercice de 1906.

div.head: CAIRO'S BEGINNINGS,
div.p: THE KHITTANS OF FUSTAT.

BY JOSEPH OFFORD. I'mder the title of "The Foundation Fustat and the Chittahs of that Town" Mr. R. Guest in the Journal of the Royal Asia Sexiety" has presented a most interesting wription of the foundation of the new Mab medan capital for Egypt, as a result of t Trab conquest.

The portions of Mr. Gnest's essay relati 1. the Arabic authorities for the foundation the city and for the late which is apparent 11 612 and 21 A.H., which year is also, 11 appears, the correct one for the surrend . Alexandria, can only be referred to her The important evidence adduced by Mr. Gue 1.) which the attention of our readers should

pecially directed is that the Khittahs Fustat were really the portions of ground o copied by the Arab warriors onder Amr durin the investment of the Roman Babylon. appears that land upon which an individual his family or retainers had cainped after th Moslem entry into Egypt, and which he, any member of his family or followers, con tinued to occupy for him, became his property at any rate so long as he himself or his repr entative remained as tenant.

The tenancy of certain plots was continue during the siege, and when the warriors let for the Delta and Alexandria campaign, afte the surrender of Babylon, they doubtless let relatives or dependants on the ground of wha was to become Fustat. When Amr returne to Cairo he does not appear to have interfere in any way in parcelling out the terrain o the new city with the view of making accessibl. thoroughfares in it, but simply left the pos sessors of the various plots on which thei tents were pitched during the siege, to remair holders thereof and erect edifices thereupon.

The origin or derivation of Khittah seem to be somewhat doubtful; it appears to be connected with the idea of "marking out with a line. Its general meaning is a holding or pitch and in the case of Fustat may be per haps most clearly, to us, represented by a

claim." But whatever the most direct sense of the word was, it carried with it the idea of original, or earliest, allotment. A Khittah in any city was a plot whose dimensions had remained identical since it was first marked off when the town arose upon the site.

The meaning of Khittah so far given is that of individual holdings, but the word was also used in a wider sense. Thus, all the family Khittahs of one tribe would amount to a large area which might be alluded to as the Khittah of that tribe. Or, a collection of closely related families, a sort of sub-tribe, might be said to have a Khittah, which would mean a section containing several separate family Khittahs. Some of the collective Khittahs however do not comply with these rules, for they included families of various tribes. These may be accounted for in various ways; some consisted of a number of families compelled to combine in order for their Khittah to have sufficient members to be entitled to a separate muster in the Divân. Another consisted of parties who arriv ed late, and so finding the other Kbittahs fully populated remained together and founded a supplementary one. But most of the irregular mixture of families in the Khittahs evidently a rose from their having been originated by the military organisation of the besieging camp. The soldiers who for army purposes were brigaded, or encamped together, remained united, subsequently as tenants of the ground their tents haul covered. It is plain that each Kittah was supposed to be somewhat approximate in size, and in the number of its inhabitants to the others, hence the larger tribal territories were subdivided into several collective, or sectional Khittahs, whilst the very small tribes or families combined to make the requisitely ample sectional Khittahs for theinselves.

It this view, that the army camping ground Was the origin of Fustat and its Khittahs, is correct, it is obvious that from a study of them and the personages who dwelt therein a good iden can be formed of the numbers of that army, and the different parts of Arabia that were represented by the soldiers who composed it.
The names of the Khittahs were preserved until the times of El Magrizi and Ibn Dug. mag, who appear to have copied their lists which give only the collective, or sectional ones from a common sonrce.

in interesting fact, derived from a study of the sites of the original Khittahs, is that the Vile was further eastward than now, so that Rodah island was almost in mid-stream. The river in fact in the time of Amr ran over what is now a width of about 250 metres of its present eastern bank. Rodah island also then extended much further to the sonth and, Mr. Cuest thinks, was much shorter at its northern end. As the river receeded from its eastern shore it of course eroded the western, or Ghizeh bank, and now flows upon that side over what a thousand years ago was dry land.

Our space will not permit us to explain the topography of the 49 Khittahs whose areas are Inore or less identified by the painstaking re. searches of Mr. Guiest. The obief one was the Khittah Ahier Rayah, wherein was the Mosque of Amr, the two houses erected by him, and those occupied by his kindred and adherents. The most northern of all the Kbittahs was that of Yashkur, which is marked by the Mosque of Ibn Talgo. The map added by Mr. Guest to his paper enables all his statements to be easily followed, and shows the primitive plan of Pustat clearly. The length of its site appears to have been about 5000 metres, whilst its width, limited probably by the necessity of being near the Nile for the sake of obtaining water, was about 1000 metres. Though to the north it extended eastward past the Mosque of Ibn Talan almost to the Sultan Hassan Mosque and western side of the present citadel square.

div.head: SYRIAN TRADERS.
div.p: The Governor General of French West Africa has received representations recently to take measures against the Syrian traders who are to he met with throughout French West Africa, but, above all, in French Guinea. 1897

These Syrians, the first of whom have not been settled in that part of the Dark Continent for more than a dozen years are now very numerous, and the European merehants comI plain strongly of the privileges they epjoy and Tof their methods of doing business. One of the advantages they possess is the facility to land without permission of the authorities, who are entirely ignorant of their position, antecedente, morality, and means of existence. As these people are frequently afflicted with contagious diseases, it is considered that their presence is dangerous to the general health of the community.

On the other hand, it is claimed that the Syrians, although only supposed to be pedlars, conduct rather important business transactions. It is even said that they often use fraudulent means of carrying on their operations of exchange with the natives. In the course of a journey which M. Ronme recently made in Guinea for the purpose of opening a new branch line, serious complaints were made to him about the Syrians. While quite recognising the danger, the Governor replied that there was no law which wonld permit of his taking special measures against them, but, without using reprisals, he could make them conform to common law.
One cannot help but think therefore, that the merchants of the Ivory Coast are going to obtain satisfaction as regards this question.
WAYBACK TIMES. The young lover of old Egypt was in despair.
"And to think," he wailed, that I should lose everything I had trying to corner the fig market. Now I do not know when we can be married. Why, I haven't even a house."
The beautiful daughter of the Nile smiled reassuringly.
"Cheer up, my dear," she whispered, "you can build the house yourself!"
"But where is the material 1"
"In our date garden. You know each of your love letters was inscribed on a brick. I have saved them all. Now get your overalls and go to work."
Thrifty indeed were the daughters of old Egypt.-Chicago News.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd'hui à 11h. 1/2 a.m.). La belle ardeur d'hier n'a été, comme nous le pensions, qu'un feu de paille ; en dépi d'une accentuation de la reprise des valeur dirigeantes à Londres, ici l'offre a prédomine la demande et l'a, pour ainsi dire étouffée. Le acheteurs ne sont évanouis de la scène. Il n'y & de nouveau plus que des vendeurs, en train d'offrir leur marchandise, sans trouver de con tre-partie. Le fait est que les transactions on été très clairsemées et sans importance et que la cote a fléchi sur la plupart des valeurs diri geantes.

Ainsi l'Agricole revient de 7 7/8 & 73/ vendeurs, la National Bank de 19 9/16 à 1: 5/16, la Delta Light de 9 1/2 à 9 7/16. Seul l'Obligation Foncier continue à remonte l'ancienne de 293 à 300 et la nouvelle de 25 à 255.

En baisse encore la Ramleh de 4 3/4 A 4 5/ vendeurs, les Dividendes Tramways d'Alexandri de 273 à 270, la Bière d'Alexandrie de 180 175 lesPrivilégiées et de 95 à 92Ples Dividendes la Banque d'Athènes de 109 à 107 1/2, 1 Comptoir de 2 3/8 l'ancienne et 2 1/4 L non velle à 2 1/4 et 21/8 respectivement l'Union Foncière de 4 1/2 à 4 3/8, la Banqu d'Orient de 115 à 114 1/2, et la Zariffa d 31/8 à 3.
Parmi les petits valeurs, la Spinning recul aussi de 5/16 à 1/4, les Cotton Mills de 3 2/6 vendeurs, la Salt and Soda Je 16/6 à 16/3 les Estates de 19/32 à 1/2, la fondateur Uni ted de 1 3/4 à 1 1/2.
Les Eaux du Caire progressent, au contraire de 112 les actions de capital et 182 les action de jouissance à 113 et 185 respectivement l'Ordinary Khedivial Mail de 18/6 à 19/6.
La Cassa di Sconto est également inscrit en reprise de 28 à 30 francs, mais sans affaires

Sur le reste de la cote il n'y a pas de char gements à signaler. Ainsi que nous le dision hier, tant qu'il n'y a rien de changé à la situ? tion tant locale que générale, il n'y a pas d reprise stable à espérer.

Du rapport du Conseil d'Administration de la Compagnie agricole du Nil, approuvé pa l'assemblée générale ordinaire tenue le 16 jui let courant & Bruxelles, il résulte que les inte rêts et commissions, bénéfices sur reventes d terrain, exploitations agricoles, etc., ont atteint pour l'exercice écoulé, 613,837 francs 13,contr 446,086 fr. 77 pour l'exercice précédent. Le frais généraux ont été de 81,810 fr. 25 contr 87,987 fr. 50. Avec l'important report de l'e xercice 1905-1906, le crédit du compte d profits et pertes s'est élevé à 732,291 fr. 74
Déduction faite des frais généraux, il es donc resté un bénéfice net de 650,481 francs 4 contre 348,237 fr. 24 précédemment.
Après prélèvement de la réserve légale amortissements, dividende de 5 % aux action et une somme de 12,857 fr. 14 pour les part: de fondateur.

Le dividende est donc de 18 fr. 75 pou l'action de capital contre 12 fr. 50 l'an dernier Les parts de fondateur reçoivent 1 franc, lais sant 857 fr. 14 å un compte "reliquat de ré partition des parts de fondateur ". Il a ét. reporté à nouveau une somme totale de 99,999 fr. 02.

Depuis la clôture de l'exercice, il a été cré 4,000 obligations de 500 francs chacune, faisan partie des 10,000 obligations dont la création est prévue par l'article 15 des statuts. Un partie des fonds en provenant a été employé dans l'affaire de la Société agricole de Kafr-el Dawar.
Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
NOTES ET CRITIQUES

Le Caire, Mardi 23 juillet. Le taux de l'escompte libre à Londres baisgé hier de 1/8 à 3 1/2 pour cent. A Stock Exchange, le Consolidé anglais a perd 1/8 à 83 7/8. L'Unifiée est restée invariée : 101 1/2. La National Bank a encore gagné 1/8 à 19. L'Agricole est demeurée inchangée 7 3/4, de même que la Daïra Sanieh à 13 5/ et la Delta Light à 9 3/4.
A Paris, le Crédit Foncier Egyptien avancé de 1 franc à 679. La Banque d'A thènes est renseignée à 109, ex.coupon.

Ainsi que nous l'avions fait pressentir, notr marché des valeurs a sensiblement accentu ce matin ses bonnes dispositions d'hier. De le début, la tenue générale a été excellente Des demandes nombreuses se sont produite sur plusieurs valeurs et, signe caractéristique les vendeurs se sont montrés réfractaires. De cidément, la croyance en un avenir meilleu: tenda Saffirmer, malgré les rumeurs ultra alarmantes que les agents da parti baissier s'é vertuent toujours à propager d'abord er Bourse, puis par l'entremise de certains jour naux. Certes, nous ne sommes pas la fin de la crise ou plutôt des conséquences naturelles de la crise ; mais il est manifeste que la baisse a été encore plus irraisonnée que la hausse d'antan. Aussi bien une réaction est forcée en il n'est pas impossible qu'elle commence cette fois, à se produire sérieusement plus to que d'ordinaire, c'est-à-dire avant l'expiration de la morte saison.
En attendant, dans le compartiment de Banques, la National, que nous avions laissée hier à 18 3/4, a clôturé aujourd'hui à 19 1/2 soit en avance de 3/4 de livre. L'Agricole passé de 7 5/8 à 7 18/16.

Les obligations A lots anciennes du Crédit Foncier ont gagné 6 francs & 295 et les nouvelles 6 francs à 257. La Dafra Sanieh a hausse à 13 1/16-1/2. L'Enterprise and Development a bénéfició de 5/16 à 8 5/16. L'Allotment a été Assez bien tend à 1 15/16 et sa part à 50.

NOTICE.

The Administration has the honour to inform the public that tenders will be received up to noon at latest on the 1st November next for the supply of two hundred thousand Pine Sleepers required for the year 1908, according to sample to be submitted to the Permanent Way Department of the said Administration, and the conditions of the specification relating to this supply, of which a copy may be obtained at the Central office of the General Stores at Boulac (Cairo) and at the office of the Inspector of Stores, Gabbary (Alexandria) against pay. ment of 100 milliemes.

All persons desiring to take part in this adjudication must first pay into the Treasury of the Administration a sum of L.E. 200 (Two hundred Egyptian pounds) as & provisional deposit. The successful tenderer must increase this sum to the amount of ten per cent of his accepted offer.
Delivery of these Sleepers is to commence 1st June 1908 at earliest, and terminate by 10th September 1908.

Tenders must be accompanied by a stamped paper of 30 milliemes as well as by the receipt for the payment of the provisional deposit above mentioned, the whole to be addressed registered post to : "The General Manager,. Egyptian State Railways,
Cairo? and in double envelopes, the inner bearing the following inscription.
"Tender for the supply of Pine Sleepers."
Any offer received later than the day and hour aforəsaid will not be taken into considera tion.
The Administration is not bound to acpept the lowest or any tender, and reserves to itself the right to divide the contract Cairo, 18th Joly 1907.

AVERTISSEMENT,
Le 13 Juillet Mr. Georges Pantélidis Agé de | 12 ans a été mordu au Casino San Stefano par tun chien de petite taille, race européenne e sous-poil fauve clair. L'animal a été conduit
au Fort Kamarleh par les soins du Caracol de Flemming et mis aussitôt sous observation.

Dès le lendemain apparaissaient une série de symptômes qui rendaient l'animal fortement suspeot. Le père de l'intéressé a été avisé que I par mesure de précaution l'enfant devrait être aussitôt dirigé sur un établissement antirabique.
Aujonrd'hui le doute n'est plus possible, l'animal se trouve dans la phase qui suit souvent l'accès de rage Purieuse (Rage Paralytique).

La Municipalité en portant ces faits à la connaissance du public a eu en vue non seulement de le mettre en garde contre l'approche de chiens inconnus qui très souvent ne présentent aucun signe apparent de rage, mais aussi de l'engager à une stricte observation des prescriptions du règlement sur les chiens qui exigent lenr musellement ou leur tenge en | laisse ; les plus graves dangers peuvent naltre en eftet d'une imprudence ou d'une inobservation de ces prescriptions. Alexandrie le 19 Juillet 1907.

L'Administration des Postes met en adju. dication la fourniture des uniformes nécessaires à son personnel pour les années 1909 1910 et 1911.

Los persannes qui désirent concourir à cette adjudication peuvent prendre connaissance du Cahier des Charges tous les jours de 9h à midi, les Dimanches exceptés, au bureau du Secrétariat de la Direction Générale des Postes à Alexandrie et au bureau du Secrétariat de la Direction Locale des Postes au Caire.

Les offres devront être faites sur le tableau annexé an Cahier des Charges et être accompagnées d'une feuille de papier timbré de P.T. a. Elles devront être insérées sous double onve| loppe, celle extérieure à l'adresse du Directeur Général des Postes à Alexandrie et celle intérieure portant la mention" Offre pour la fourniture des Uniformes."
Les offres devant parvenir à la Direction Générale des Postes au plus tard le 31 Janvier
1908 à 10 h. a.m. | L'Administration se réserve le droit d'accepter l'offre qui lui semblera la plus avantageuse et même celui de ne pas donner suite à l'adju. dication.

div.head: THE STANDARD LIFE ASSURANCE CO.
ESTABLISHED 1825.
div.p: ACCUMULATED FUNDS £11,750,000.
NEW SCHEMES OF ASSURANCE.
ENDOWMENT ASSURANCES with guaranteed bonus on survival of 2 per annum for each 100 of assurance.
CHILDREN'S ENDOWMENTS at low rates, with return of all premiums paid in the event of death before the given age is attained.
EXAMPLES:

ENDOWMENT ASSURANCES WITH GUARANTEED BONUS ON SURVIVAL.-A, aged 30 next birthday, with Good prospect of longevity, takes out a Policy of £1,000 under this table for an Endowment Assurance payable at the age of 60 or earlier death, with a Guaranteed Bonus of 40s. per cent per annum. If he survives the fixed term, the annual premium for which will be £38:15:0. In the event of death within the 30 yearsm only the sum assured in the Policy is payable, viz:- £1,000, but if he survives the term, he is entitled to receive besides £1,000, a Guaranteed Bonus of 30 times 40s. per cent; i.c. £800, or in all £600; and similarly for other periods and rates, Premiums can be paid quarterly or half-yearly if desired.

CHILDREN'S ENDOWMENT.- An annual Premium of £18:1:3 will provide a child aged 1 next birthday with an Endowment of £500 on attaining the age of 21. In the event of the child's death before the given age is attained, all the premiums paid to the Company will be return to the parent. Premiums can be paid quarterly or half-yearly if desired. Should the parent wish to discontinue the payment of premiums, he can claim a surrender value of 90 per cent of all the annual premiums paid by him, excepting the first, providing three full years premiums have been paid and the transaction is completed while the Policy is in force. Should the parent not wish to take the surrender value, he has the option, after three full years' premiums have been paid, of receiving a Paid-up Policy for such a proportion of the original Sum Assured as the number of payments made bears to the whole number payable. If written application be made and the transaction completed within the days of grace, and provided such proportion be not less than £50.
For Prospectus, Forms of Proposal and all particulars, apply to the STANDARD LIFE OFFICE, STANDARD BUILDINGS, CAIRO.
